ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to better study math as well as most of the Calc 1 concepts.
My critical thinking skills improved and I developed a better understanding of Calc 1 concepts.
Taking Math 112 helped open my eyes to thinking in an analytical way. I had to practice time management skills and responsible study habits as well.
I learned the fundamentals of calculus.
More thorough understanding of how derivatives relate to rate of change, of relations between function/1st/2nd derivative. More comprehensive understanding of the subject in general.
I developed problem solving skills and the ability to look at problems with a mathematical view.
I improved my problem solving skills and refreshed my knowledge of Calculus.
Like any math class, you learn and develop skills that you had prior and this class was great in that regard!

I learned how to compute limits and how to define the derivative through limits. I learned how to derive functions and apply the knowledge in real world situation. I also learned how to integrate functions.
I learned how to apply math theory to problems.
Learned a lot about limits and derivatives and a little about integrals and differential equations.
Understanding of limits and how they work

I learned how to apply calculus to real world applications
I also learned how to effectively problem solve when the answers are not right in front of me

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was a lot of support offered which I think was really good and needed. The way the presentations were set up did not always help teach the lesson. I found more luck with videos on youtube, that is how I came to understand most of the concepts.
I would have liked more practice problems outside of class and problem sets.

The strengths of this course are the seminar-size classes. I felt like I was able to get to know my professor and classmates well. The weakness of this course lied in the problem sets. I dont think the content of the problem sets lined up very well with the content of the class.
More math examples instead of reviewing definitions and exceptions would have been more helpful.

By not writing all-or-nothing high stakes multiple choice questions, problem sets were unnecessarily difficult in comparison to the content taught in the course and the tests and oftentimes didn't help me do well on the tests. 

Professor did excellent job of explaining content and always made sure to do many examples.

Some of the strengths included all the practice problems we completed in class. Also, the willingness of the professor to help answers questions that students in the class had. Overall, no weaknesses about this course.
Strengths were the engaging pset questions and office hours, weaknesses was the slow pace of the class.
Strengths are the small class size and many resources to get the topics. Weaknesses are the differences in teaching across sections.

Strengths: There were a lot of office hours and tutoring options available.

Weaknesses: In class it felt like we barely skimmed the surface of concepts that we would later be expected to understand in more depth.
The course is well-structured and the textbook provides lots of exercises to learn the material. Practice exams were also very helpful, but having even more of them would be an improvement.
A strength is that It teaches you to understand what you are being taught not just learn it. I think there could be more resources to help study and prepare for midterms and finals

Strengths: Professors are very engaged with the students and are flexible, class was a mix of lectures and practice problems, engaged students with each other

Weaknesses: Slides that were posted only showed as they were presented, but did not show the solutions and problem steps

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend this course only if they were going to be taught certain professors and if they are willing to put in work outside of class to teach themselves concepts.
Yes, I would recommend this course.
I would most likely recommend this course to another student. It is foundational to learn Calc 1 and I dont regret taking the class at all. Im grateful for the experience of taking this class.
Only if it is required by your major, don't take if not.
If you need it for a requirement, yes. Otherwise, I dont see any good reason to take it.

Math 112 was significantly more difficult than my high school calculus class although all of the content was the same. Take if you have to for a major requirement, but otherwise you should probably avoid it if calculus isn't applicable to you.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students because it was an intellectual challenging class. Also, I feel like the content taught in this class is important for the real world.
I would recommend this course to students to help them engage their critical thinking muscles.
Yes, even if they dont like maths. Calculus help you think critically and give you skills applicable to many real-world scenarios.
If you do not need this course for your major or do not enjoy math, I would not recommend it. The course requires a decent time commitment that would likely not feel worth it.

Absolutely. I believe everyone should learn the basics of Calculus (which you learn in this course) regardless of major. This course works great both for people in STEM and for those who might not love math.
Yeah its a good introduction to calculus and maths at Yale
Yes, the course teaches you how to effectively solve problems that are not straightforward, and it also applies calculus to real world instances
